content: Since the mid-1980s, Congress has passed legislation to support older youth in foster care through the Chafee Foster Care Independence Program (CFCIP), providing services like housing. States have developed independent living programs with funding from CFCIP to help youth attain self-sufficiency. Despite these efforts, research shows that current and former foster youth face challenges compared to their peers in the general population. Research shows that current and former foster youth struggle more than their peers in transitioning to adulthood. Former foster youth are more likely to forgo higher education, have fair or poor health, become homeless, and rely on public support. Efforts by policy makers and advocates have brought attention to these challenges, leading to initiatives to provide support beyond the age of 18.
